trans-unit.source: Configuring deadlock detection and lock wait timeouts

seg-source.mrk: Configuring deadlock detection and lock wait timeouts

target.mrk: Configuring deadlock detection and lock wait timeouts

trans-unit.source: You configure the amount of time a transaction waits before does any deadlock checking with the derby.locks.deadlockTimeout property.

seg-source.mrk: You configure the amount of time a transaction waits before does any deadlock checking with the derby.locks.deadlockTimeout property.

target.mrk: You configure the amount of time a transaction waits before does any deadlock checking with the derby.locks.deadlockTimeout property.

seg-source.mrk: configuring lock wait timeouts

target.mrk: configuring lock wait timeouts

trans-unit.source: You configure the amount of time a transaction waits before timing out with the derby.locks.waitTimeout property. When configuring your database or system, you should consider these properties together. For example, in order for any deadlock checking to occur, the derby.locks.deadlockTimeout property must be set to a value lower than the derby.locks.waitTimeout property. If it is set to a value equal to or higher than the derby.locks.waitTimeout, the transaction times out before does any deadlock checking.

seg-source.mrk: You configure the amount of time a transaction waits before timing out with the derby.locks.waitTimeout property.
When configuring your database or system, you should consider these properties together.
For example, in order for any deadlock checking to occur, the derby.locks.deadlockTimeout property must be set to a value lower than the derby.locks.waitTimeout property.
If it is set to a value equal to or higher than the derby.locks.waitTimeout, the transaction times out before does any deadlock checking.

target.mrk: You configure the amount of time a transaction waits before timing out with the derby.locks.waitTimeout property.
When configuring your database or system, you should consider these properties together.
For example, in order for any deadlock checking to occur, the derby.locks.deadlockTimeout property must be set to a value lower than the derby.locks.waitTimeout property.
If it is set to a value equal to or higher than the derby.locks.waitTimeout, the transaction times out before does any deadlock checking.

seg-source.mrk: Deadlocks

target.mrk: Deadlocks

seg-source.mrk: detecting

target.mrk: detecting

trans-unit.source: By default, derby.locks.waitTimeout is set to 60 seconds. -1 is the equivalent of no wait timeout. This means that transactions never time out, although can choose a transaction as a deadlock victim.

seg-source.mrk: By default, derby.locks.waitTimeout is set to 60 seconds.
-1 is the equivalent of no wait timeout.
This means that transactions never time out, although <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> can choose a transaction as a deadlock victim.

target.mrk: By default, derby.locks.waitTimeout is set to 60 seconds.
-1 is the equivalent of no wait timeout.
This means that transactions never time out, although <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> can choose a transaction as a deadlock victim.

trans-unit.source: In the following figure, derby.locks.deadlockTimeout is set to 30 seconds, while derby.locks.waitTimeout has no limit.

seg-source.mrk: In the following figure, derby.locks.deadlockTimeout is set to 30 seconds, while derby.locks.waitTimeout has no limit.

target.mrk: In the following figure, derby.locks.deadlockTimeout is set to 30 seconds, while derby.locks.waitTimeout has no limit.

trans-unit.source: Configuration with deadlock checking after 30 seconds and no lock wait timeouts

seg-source.mrk: Configuration with deadlock checking after 30 seconds and no lock wait timeouts

target.mrk: Configuration with deadlock checking after 30 seconds and no lock wait timeouts

trans-unit.source: <alt>This figure shows a configuration in which transactions are never aborted unless they are selected as the victim when deadlocks are checked. If at 30 seconds there is no deadlock, the transaction will wait until it can obtain a lock (or forever).</alt>

seg-source.mrk: <alt>This figure shows a configuration in which transactions are never aborted unless they are selected as the victim when deadlocks are checked.
If at 30 seconds there is no deadlock, the transaction will wait until it can obtain a lock (or forever).</alt>

target.mrk: <alt>This figure shows a configuration in which transactions are never aborted unless they are selected as the victim when deadlocks are checked.
If at 30 seconds there is no deadlock, the transaction will wait until it can obtain a lock (or forever).</alt>

trans-unit.source: In the following figure, derby.locks.deadlockTimeout is set to 60 seconds, while derby.locks.waitTimeout is set to 90 seconds.

seg-source.mrk: In the following figure, derby.locks.deadlockTimeout is set to 60 seconds, while derby.locks.waitTimeout is set to 90 seconds.

target.mrk: In the following figure, derby.locks.deadlockTimeout is set to 60 seconds, while derby.locks.waitTimeout is set to 90 seconds.

trans-unit.source: Configuration with deadlock checking after 60 seconds and lock wait timeout at 90 seconds

seg-source.mrk: Configuration with deadlock checking after 60 seconds and lock wait timeout at 90 seconds

target.mrk: Configuration with deadlock checking after 60 seconds and lock wait timeout at 90 seconds

trans-unit.source: <alt>This figure shows a configuration where deadlock checking occurs after a transaction has waited 60 seconds for a lock. After it has waited for 90 seconds, the transaction times out and is rolled back.</alt>

seg-source.mrk: <alt>This figure shows a configuration where deadlock checking occurs after a transaction has waited 60 seconds for a lock.
After it has waited for 90 seconds, the transaction times out and is rolled back.</alt>

target.mrk: <alt>This figure shows a configuration where deadlock checking occurs after a transaction has waited 60 seconds for a lock.
After it has waited for 90 seconds, the transaction times out and is rolled back.</alt>

trans-unit.source: In the following figure, derby.locks.deadlockTimeout is set to 60 seconds, while derby.locks.waitTimeout is set to 50 seconds, lower than the deadlock timeout limit.

seg-source.mrk: In the following figure, derby.locks.deadlockTimeout is set to 60 seconds, while derby.locks.waitTimeout is set to 50 seconds, lower than the deadlock timeout limit.

target.mrk: In the following figure, derby.locks.deadlockTimeout is set to 60 seconds, while derby.locks.waitTimeout is set to 50 seconds, lower than the deadlock timeout limit.

trans-unit.source: Configuration with no deadlock checking and a 50-second lock wait timeout

seg-source.mrk: Configuration with no deadlock checking and a 50-second lock wait timeout

target.mrk: Configuration with no deadlock checking and a 50-second lock wait timeout

trans-unit.source: <alt>This figure shows a configuration where no deadlock checking occurs. The transactions time out after they have waited 50 seconds.</alt>

seg-source.mrk: <alt>This figure shows a configuration where no deadlock checking occurs.
The transactions time out after they have waited 50 seconds.</alt>
